Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity Phenomena of Higher Rank Actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project belongs to the field of dynamical systems, which aims to understand long-term behaviors of movements that take place over time in a geometric space and are governed by a fixed set of mathematical rules. The theory of dynamical systems has its roots in celestial mechanics and has become an important tool in many other scientific fields. The proposed research deals with a special class of dynamical systems, where the rules governing the movement form a sufficiently large group so that a point is allowed to move in one of several possible ways in each step. In such cases, there is often a small collection of possible structures that remain unchanged over time. The goal of this project is to determine such structures. The PI will conduct research on the topic, collaborate with other researchers, work with graduate and undergraduate students, and disseminate ideas developed in the project.

This research will study dynamical systems of group actions. The principal objects are actions on tori, nilmanifolds and other homogeneous spaces by higher-rank commutative groups or by lattices in higher-rank semisimple Lie groups. These actions are often expected to have rigidity, a phenomenon characterized by the scarcity of invariant structures under the action. The main objective is to classify such group actions under suitable assumptions, as well as invariant structures under these actions. The method of the research will combine tools from ergodic theory, smooth dynamics and representation theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sponsored research was in the mathematical domain of dynamical systems. The field of dynamical systems originated from the study of the movement of planets and in general studies the movements of a point in a space governed by a given set of rules. The funded project focused on the rigidity phenomena in dynamical systems. Roughly speaking, rigidity means how, under certain conditions, the trajectories of a dynamical system must approximate those of a prescribed system that is better understood. Two topics involved in the sponsored research are: (1) when the dynamical system is given by the action of a certain class of very large groups, called higher rank lattices, how the action should approximate affine actions; (2) when the dynamical systems has very low complexity or is given by simple rules called skew products, how the trajectories should appear to be periodic for very long time; and how this can be applied to the Mobius disjointness conjecture.

On the first topic, the PI, in a series of joint works with A. Brown and F. Rodriguez Hertz, discovered a non-resonance principle that lead to the smooth rigidity classification of Anosov actions on nilmanifolds by higher rank lattices, as well as to a criterion for the existence of an invariant probability measure under higher rank lattices. On the second topic, the PI solved the Mobius disjointness problem for analytic skew products on the two dimensional torus; this was later generalized by the PI and M. Litman to nonlinear skew product flows on the Heisenberg nilmanifold. Moreover, the PI, with W. Huang and X. Ye, also provided a sufficient condition for Möbius disjointness in terms of subpolynomial measure complexity growth.

During the funded period, the PI spoke at various seminars and conferences to disseminate the ideas developed in the research to the mathematical community. The PI served as the co-advisor of graduate students. The PI also gave seminar talks on related research topics to undergraduate audiences on multiple occasions. The PI also initiated and organized an annual educational program, Math Outing for Undergraduates, that brings 12-20 undergraduate students during a weekend to explore a research topic in mathematics.
